elements.content: Two new 3D NaCl-type frameworks of [M(pyrazine)2NO2]ClO4 (M = Co, Cu), consist of (4, 4) sheets of metal−pyrazine connected by μ1,3-nitrito, representing the first examples of μ1,3-nitrito bridges and exhibiting antiferromagnetism.
elements.clean_text: Two new 3D NaCl-type frameworks of [M(pyrazine)2NO2]ClO4 (M = Co, Cu), consist of (4, 4) sheets of metal-pyrazine connected by μ1,3-nitrito, representing the first examples of μ1,3-nitrito bridges and exhibiting antiferromagnetism.

elements.content: [M(pyrazine)2NO2]ClO4 (M = Co, Cu), two 3D NaCl-type frameworks possessing (4, 4) sheets of metal−pyrazine linked by a μ1,3-nitrito and exhibiting antiferromagnetism, represent the first examples of magnetic frameworks containing μ1,3-nitrito bridges.
elements.clean_text: [M(pyrazine)2NO2]ClO4 (M = Co, Cu), two 3D NaCl-type frameworks possessing (4, 4) sheets of metal-pyrazine linked by a μ1,3-nitrito and exhibiting antiferromagnetism, represent the first examples of magnetic frameworks containing μ1,3-nitrito bridges.

elements.content: The nitrito group (NO2 -) is unique among the short ligands because it can coordinate metal ions in a variety of ways (Chart ) in which several are not observed for other ligands (Chart e,f,i). As a monodentate ligand, it can use either N or O atoms (Chart a−c), while as a bidentate ligand, four modes have been observed (Chart d−g), chelating or bridging either through both N and O or through O only, and as a tridentate ligand (Chart i, j), it can chelate one metal through two O atoms and bridge another via a N or O atom. Many polynuclear compounds, such as dinuclear, trinuclear, pentanuclear, heptanuclear, and 1D polymeric ones, have been synthesized and characterized, and magnetic-mediating characters of the bridging nitrite have been investigated. For example, the two-atom O/N-bridging mode (Chart e) shows moderate antiferromagnetic interaction as observed in several 1D Ni2+ chains, while a Ni−Mn−Ni trinuclear complex involving the same bridging nitrite as well as azido bridges was reported to show ferromagnetic behavior. For the single-atom O bridge mode (Chart g), weak ferromagnetic interaction was found in a dinuclear Cu2+ complex. The tridentate mode (Chart j) displays moderate antiferromagnetic interaction in a dinuclear Ni2+ compound2b with a combination of chelation at one Ni2+, while the same mode mediates very weak antiferromagnetic interaction in an alternating Cu2+ chain6j together with bridging oxamidato and nitrito ligands, and a very weak ferromagnetic interaction was observed in a Ni−Cu bimetallic chain6k with bidentate nitrito coordination at Ni2+. In despite of these reports, to the best of our knowledge, no 2D or 3D polymeric complexes containing nitrito bridges have been documented. On the other hand, pyrazine (pyz) is of benefit for constructing high-dimensional frameworks because it is a good linker as well as a magnetic mediator. Many magnetic systems involving pyz and other short ligands such as cyanide, azide, diacyanamide, and formate have been explored. In this work, we utilize pyz with nitrite to explore whether high-dimensional frameworks can be obtained. Reported here are two new 3D NaCl-type frameworks of [M(pyz)2NO2]ClO4 (1Co, M = Co; 2Cu, M = Cu), consisting of (4, 4) sheets of metal−pyz linked by μ1,3-nitrito bridges. They are the first examples of a nitrite ion in this bridging manner (Chart h). Both materials are antiferromagnets.
elements.clean_text: The nitrito group (NO2 -) is unique among the short ligands because it can coordinate metal ions in a variety of ways (Chart ) in which several are not observed for other ligands (Chart e,f,i). As a monodentate ligand, it can use either N or O atoms (Chart a-c), while as a bidentate ligand, four modes have been observed (Chart d-g), chelating or bridging either through both N and O or through O only, and as a tridentate ligand (Chart i, j), it can chelate one metal through two O atoms and bridge another via a N or O atom. Many polynuclear compounds, such as dinuclear, trinuclear, pentanuclear, heptanuclear, and 1D polymeric ones, have been synthesized and characterized, and magnetic-mediating characters of the bridging nitrite have been investigated. For example, the two-atom O/N-bridging mode (Chart e) shows moderate antiferromagnetic interaction as observed in several 1D Ni2+ chains, while a Ni-Mn-Ni trinuclear complex involving the same bridging nitrite as well as azido bridges was reported to show ferromagnetic behavior. For the single-atom O bridge mode (Chart g), weak ferromagnetic interaction was found in a dinuclear Cu2+ complex. The tridentate mode (Chart j) displays moderate antiferromagnetic interaction in a dinuclear Ni2+ compound2b with a combination of chelation at one Ni2+, while the same mode mediates very weak antiferromagnetic interaction in an alternating Cu2+ chain6j together with bridging oxamidato and nitrito ligands, and a very weak ferromagnetic interaction was observed in a Ni-Cu bimetallic chain6k with bidentate nitrito coordination at Ni2+. In despite of these reports, to  the best of our knowledge, no 2D or 3D polymeric complexes containing nitrito bridges have been documented. On the other hand, pyrazine (pyz) is of benefit for constructing high-dimensional frameworks because it is a good linker as well as a magnetic mediator. Many magnetic systems involving pyz and other short ligands such as cyanide, azide, diacyanamide, and formate have been explored. In this work, we utilize pyz with nitrite to explore whether high-dimensional frameworks can be obtained. Reported here are two new 3D NaCl-type frameworks of [M(pyz)2NO2]ClO4 (1Co, M = Co; 2Cu, M = Cu), consisting of (4, 4) sheets of metal-pyz linked by μ1,3-nitrito bridges. They are the first examples of a nitrite ion in this bridging manner (Chart h). Both materials are antiferromagnets.

elements.content: Different Coordination Modes of the Nitrite Ion Observed in Literatures Where Mode h Is Reported for the First Time in This Work
elements.clean_text: 1  Different Coordination Modes of the Nitrite Ion Observed in Literatures Where Mode h Is Reported for the First Time in This Work

elements.content: The reaction of metal salts, Co(ClO4)2·6H2O for 1Co and Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O for 2Cu, NaNO2, and pyz produced crystals of the two isomorphs whose structures were determined by X-ray diffraction. The structure (Figures and S1 of the Supporting Information) consists of metal−pyz (4, 4) layers parallel to the ab plane further linked by μ1,3-nitrito along the c direction, affording a NaCl-like framework, with ClO4 - lying in the cubic cavities. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that the μ1,3-nitrito bridge (Chart h) is observed. In both structures, there is only one unique M2+ center possessing a slightly compressed (1Co) or elongated (2Cu) octahedral environment, with the four N atoms of the pyz ligands in the equatorial plane and the two O atoms of the nitrito groups at the apical positions. The unique M−N/O bonds are 2.160/2.068 Å (1Co) and 2.049/2.285 Å (2Cu), and all N/O−M−N/O angles are ideal 90 or 180°. The O−N−O angle of NO2 -, in the structures, is 180°, not bent as documented. However, the flat, disklike thermal ellipse of N/O atoms (Figure S1a of the Supporting Information) revealed the bent characteristic of NO2 -. The thermal ellipses have their long axes (U 11 = U 22, the principal mean-square atomic displacements) perpendicular, while the short one (U 33) parallel to the M···M line or the 4-fold axis, and the ratio of U 11/U 33 is ca. 3 and 7 for the O and N of NO2 -, respectively (CIF files of the Supporting Information). The NO2 - group could not be modeled out of the 4-fold axis in the structure calculation. This indicates that the bent NO2 - locates randomly or rotates around the M···M line. The M···M distances spanned by pyz are 7.128 Å (1Co) and 6.877 Å (2Cu), while those via NO2 - are 6.199 Å (1Co) and 6.646 Å (2Cu). The pyz ring is titled toward the MN4 basal plane, with the titling angles being 55.0° (1Co) and 59.7° (2Cu). The ClO4 - anion in the cubic cavity (Figure S1b of the Supporting Information) forms weak H bonding of O···H−C with pyz, with C···O distances of ca. 3.3 Å and C−H···O angles of 133°. It seems that the ClO4 - anion plays an important templating role in the formation of the framework.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of metal salts, Co(ClO4)2⋅6H2O for 1Co and Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O for 2Cu, NaNO2, and pyz produced crystals of the two isomorphs whose structures were determined by X-ray diffraction. The structure (Figures  and S1 of the Supporting Information) consists of metal-pyz (4, 4) layers parallel to the ab plane further linked by μ1,3-nitrito along the c direction, affording a NaCl-like framework, with ClO4 - lying in the cubic cavities. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that the μ1,3-nitrito bridge (Chart h) is observed. In both structures, there is only one unique M2+ center possessing a slightly compressed (1Co) or elongated (2Cu) octahedral environment, with the four N atoms of the pyz ligands in the equatorial plane and the two O atoms of the nitrito groups at the apical positions. The unique M-N/O bonds are 2.160/2.068 Å (1Co) and 2.049/2.285 Å (2Cu), and all N/O-M-N/O angles are ideal 90 or 180°. The O-N-O angle of NO2 -, in the structures, is 180°, not bent as documented. However, the flat, disklike thermal ellipse of N/O atoms (Figure S1a of the Supporting Information) revealed the bent characteristic of NO2 -. The thermal ellipses have their long axes (U 11 = U 22, the principal mean-square atomic displacements) perpendicular, while the short one (U 33) parallel to the M⋅⋅⋅M line or the 4-fold axis, and the ratio of U 11/U 33 is ca. 3 and 7 for the O and N of NO2 -, respectively (CIF files of the Supporting Information). The NO2 - group could not be modeled out of the 4-fold axis in the structure calculation. This indicates that the bent NO2 - locates randomly or rotates around the M⋅⋅⋅M line. The M⋅⋅⋅M distances spanned by pyz are 7.128 Å (1Co) and 6.877 Å (2Cu), while those via NO2 - are 6.199 Å (1Co) and 6.646 Å (2Cu). The pyz ring is titled toward the MN4 basal plane, with the titling angles being 55.0° (1Co) and 59.7° (2Cu). The ClO4 - anion in the cubic cavity (Figure S1b of the Supporting Information) forms weak H bonding of O⋅⋅⋅H-C with pyz, with C⋅⋅⋅O distances of ca. 3.3 Å and C-H⋅⋅⋅O angles of 133°. It seems that the ClO4 - anion plays an important templating role in the formation of the framework.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibilities of 1Co and 2Cu measured under 1 kOe field are represented in Figure . At room temperature, the χT values are 3.18 cm3 K mol-1 for 1Co and 0.51 cm3 K mol-1 for 2Cu, being close to those expected for Co2+ with S = 3/2 and Cu2+ with S = 1/2. Upon cooling, the χT values decrease more and more rapidly for both complexes, indicating antiferromagnetic behavior. The maxima of χ are observed at 9.4 K for 1Co and 6.7 K for 2Cu, suggesting antiferromagnetic ordering. The Neel temperatures, T N's, determined by the peaks of d(χT)/dT, are 6.0 K for 1Co and 4.0 K for 2Cu. The field-dependent magnetizations (Figure , inset), even at 2 K and 50 kOe, being 0.47 Nβ (1Co) and 0.21 Nβ (2Cu), far from the saturated values, confirm the significant antiferromagnetic interactions in both materials. The ac susceptibility data (Figure S2 of the Supporting Information) for both materials show broad maxima in the in-phase components while almost no out-of-phase response, indicating the long-range antiferromagnetic ordering. The rise in χ and the in-phase component of 1Co below 3 K is probably due to the small amount of impurity in the sample.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibilities of 1Co and 2Cu measured under 1 kOe field are represented in Figure . At room temperature, the χT values are 3.18 cm3 K mol-1 for 1Co and 0.51 cm3 K mol-1 for 2Cu, being close to those expected for Co2+ with S = 3/2 and Cu2+ with S = 1/2. Upon cooling, the χT values decrease more and more rapidly for both complexes, indicating antiferromagnetic behavior. The maxima of χ are observed at 9.4 K for 1Co and 6.7 K for 2Cu, suggesting antiferromagnetic ordering. The Neel temperatures, T N's, determined by the peaks of d(χT)/dT, are 6.0 K for 1Co and 4.0 K for 2Cu. The field-dependent magnetizations (Figure , inset), even at 2 K and 50 kOe, being 0.47  Nβ (1Co) and 0.21 Nβ (2Cu), far from the saturated values, confirm the significant antiferromagnetic interactions in both materials. The ac susceptibility data (Figure S2 of the Supporting Information) for both materials show broad maxima in the in-phase components while almost no out-of-phase response, indicating the long-range antiferromagnetic ordering. The rise in χ and the in-phase component of 1Co below 3 K is probably due to the small amount of impurity in the sample.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of1Co and 2Cu under an applied field of 1 kOe with the best-fitting data as red lines. Inset:  field-dependent magnetization of 1Co and 2Cu at 2.0 K.
elements.clean_text: 2  Temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of1Co and 2Cu under an applied field of 1 kOe with the best-fitting data as red lines. Inset: field-dependent magnetization of 1Co and 2Cu at 2.0 K.

elements.content: Regarding the structure feature, two magnetic exchange pathways are possible:  via pyz and μ1,3-nitrito. For 1Co, the Lines model for a 3D simple cubic lattice was found to fit the high-temperature magnetic data best, though 2D quadratic-layer14 or 1D Fisher models could be used (see the Supporting Information). Therefore, the 3D model with H = JS i ·S j was applied, where the impurity was considered as a Curie paramagnetic contribution. The best fitting of the magnetic data above 50 K gave J = −4.26(2) cm-1 and g = 2.790(3) with an agreement factor of R = 7.9 × 10-6 (R = ∑(χo − χc)2/∑χo 2). The J value means that in 1Co the coupling between Co2+ ions via a pyz bridge is several times larger than those of the previous studies, though it is an average coupling intermediated by both pyz and μ1,3-nitrito. This might be due to the shorter Co−Npyz bond in 1Co.
elements.clean_text: Regarding the structure feature, two magnetic exchange pathways are possible: via pyz and μ1,3-nitrito. For 1Co, the Lines model for a 3D simple cubic lattice was found to fit the high-temperature magnetic data best, though 2D quadratic-layer14 or 1D Fisher models could be used (see the Supporting Information). Therefore, the 3D model with H = JS  i ⋅S  j  was applied, where the impurity was considered as a Curie paramagnetic contribution. The best fitting of the magnetic data above 50 K gave J = -4.26(2) cm-1 and g = 2.790(3) with an agreement factor of R = 7.9 × 10-6 (R = ∑(χo - χc)2/∑χo 2). The J value means that in 1Co the coupling between Co2+ ions via a pyz bridge is several times larger than those of the previous studies, though it is an average coupling intermediated by both pyz and μ1,3-nitrito. This might be due to the shorter Co-Npyz bond in 1Co.

elements.content: For 2Cu, the case is different. It has been proposed that, for pyz-bridged Cu2+ systems where the magnetic orbital is d x 2 - y 2 , the overlap between the d x 2 - y 2 orbital and the pyz π orbitals determines the magnitude of the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction. The CNDO/2 calculation showed that the π(b1g) orbital is the highest-occupied pyz π molecular orbital and mainly C-characterized. If the pyz ring is coplanar with the Cu2+ basal plane, the π system of pyz would be orthogonal to the d x 2 - y 2 orbital and antiferromagnetic interaction would not be observed. This was invoked as the reason for the absence of an antiferromagnetic exchange interaction in polymeric compound [Cu(pyzA)2(ClO4)2] n , where pyzA is pyrazine-2-carboxamide. Titling of the pyz ring relative to the basal plane leads to a possible overlap of the pyz π orbitals with the Cu d x 2 - y 2 orbital. This case was observed for polymeric [Cu(NO3)2(pyz)] x , where the pyz ring is 50° titled to the Cu basal plane. The compound shows an antiferromagnetic interaction with J = −7.4 cm-1. In Cu(pyz)2(ClO4)2, the titling angle of 66.1° leads to an antiferromagnetic interaction of J = −5.3 cm-1. In 2Cu, the elongated octahedron of Cu2+ indicates that the magnetic orbital is d x 2 - y 2 , whereas the μ1,3-nitrito ligands are at the apical positions. Consequently, the interaction between two magnetic orbitals of Cu ions through μ1,3-nitrito is expected to be weak. On the basis of the above analysis, 2Cu can be magnetically considered as square layers of Cu−pyz. Therefore, χ data of 2Cu above 10 K were fitted by Lines' quadratic-layer antiferromagnet model with H = JS i ·S j (see the Supporting Information). The best fitting produced J = −6.19(3) cm-1 and g = 2.288(7) with R = 3.4 × 10-5 (R defined as before). The J value is comparable to the aforementioned ones.
elements.clean_text: For 2Cu, the case is different. It has been proposed that, for pyz-bridged Cu2+ systems where the magnetic orbital is d x   2  -  y   2 , the overlap between the d x   2  -  y   2  orbital and the pyz π orbitals determines the magnitude of the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction. The CNDO/2 calculation showed that the π(b1g) orbital is the highest-occupied pyz π molecular orbital and mainly C-characterized. If the pyz ring is coplanar with the Cu2+ basal plane, the π system of pyz would be orthogonal to the d x   2  -  y   2  orbital and antiferromagnetic interaction would not be observed. This was invoked as the reason for the absence of an antiferromagnetic exchange interaction in polymeric compound [Cu(pyzA)2(ClO4)2] n , where pyzA is pyrazine-2-carboxamide. Titling of the pyz ring relative to the basal plane leads to a possible overlap of the pyz π orbitals with the Cu d x   2  -  y   2  orbital. This case was observed for polymeric [Cu(NO3)2(pyz)] x , where the pyz ring is 50° titled to the Cu basal plane. The compound shows an antiferromagnetic interaction with J = -7.4 cm-1. In Cu(pyz)2(ClO4)2, the titling angle of 66.1° leads to an antiferromagnetic interaction of J = -5.3 cm-1. In 2Cu, the elongated octahedron of Cu2+ indicates that the magnetic orbital is d x   2  -  y   2 , whereas the μ1,3-nitrito ligands are at the apical positions. Consequently, the interaction between two magnetic orbitals of Cu ions through μ1,3-nitrito is expected to be weak. On the basis of the above analysis, 2Cu can be magnetically considered as square layers of Cu-pyz. Therefore, χ data of 2Cu above 10 K were fitted by Lines' quadratic-layer antiferromagnet model with H = JS  i ⋅S  j  (see the Supporting Information). The best fitting produced J = -6.19(3) cm-1 and g = 2.288(7) with R = 3.4 × 10-5 (R defined as before). The J value is comparable to the aforementioned ones.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have synthesized two new magnetic 3D NaCl-like networks in which the metal ions are linked by pyz into (4, 4) sheets and further linked by a μ1,3-nitrito group. They provide the first examples containing a μ1,3-nitrito bridge. Furthermore, magnetic investigation reveals that the μ1,3-nitrite bridge can transmit antiferromagnetic interaction in the case of Co2+. To understand the magnetic-mediating character of this new μ1,3 bridge, more homo- or heterometal complexes containing μ1,3-nitrito bridges should be synthesized and characterized, and endeavors are in progress along this line.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have synthesized two new magnetic 3D NaCl-like networks in which the metal ions are linked by pyz into (4, 4) sheets and further linked by a μ1,3-nitrito group. They provide the first examples containing a μ1,3-nitrito bridge. Furthermore, magnetic investigation reveals that the μ1,3-nitrite bridge can transmit antiferromagnetic interaction in the case of Co2+. To understand the magnetic-mediating character of this new μ1,3 bridge, more homo- or heterometal complexes containing μ1,3-nitrito bridges should be synthesized and characterized, and endeavors are in progress along this line.

metadata.title:
NaCl-Type Frameworks of [M(pyrazine)2NO2]ClO4 (M = Co, Cu), the First
Examples Containing μ1,3-Nitrito Bridges Showing Antiferromagnetism
